newsitem.title: JAPAN: Softbank to raise funds for broadcasting business.
newsitem.headline: Softbank to raise funds for broadcasting business.

text.p: Japan's aggressively expanding Softbank Corp said on Tuesday it would raise 54 billion yen ($482 million) in Japan's stock and bond markets to fund its latest business target -- digital satellite broadcasting.

Softbank, already absorbing large amounts of funds to support a series of bold investments, said it would issue 4.7 million new shares and float convertible bonds worth 10 billion yen ($89.2 million).

Talk that Softbank would tap deep into the markets depressed the company's share price. It tumbled by its daily limit on the over-the-counter market in heavy trade, and was quoted at 8,990 yen in the early afternoon on Tuesday, down 1,000 yen ($8).
Traders said the expectation fuelled fears of an oversupply of Softbank shares.
Last November, Softbank raised 66.5 billion yen ($593 million) from the stock market by issuing 2.8 million new shares.

This was in addition to aggressive borrowing from the bond market -- 90 billion yen ($803 million) through straight bond issues and 70 billion yen ($625 million) in convertible bond issues last business year alone.

Softbank, which has become world's largest computer-related magazine and book publisher through a string of bold buyouts, said the new funds would be used for the launch of a new digital satellite television service, J-SkyB.
Softbank launched the joint venture in the summer with international media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's News Corp.
The two bought 21.4 percent of Japan's nationwide television network Asahi National Broadcasting in June.
Softbank president Masayoshi Son said earlier this month that digital satellite broadcasting would be Softbank's business focus for the next year or two.
Analysts expect more than 100 billion yen ($892 million) will be required to launch the satellite broadcasting business.

Softbank has said Son's comments marked at least a temporary halt to a buying spree which culminated in the purchase in September of an 80 percent stake in Kingston Technology Corp, a leading supplier of memory modules, for cash and stock worth some $1.5 billion.

Within the past year, Softbank has completed $2.1 billion acquisition of Ziff-Davis Publishing, and last year spent some $800 million for the Interface Group, whose trade show portfolio includes Comdex, the largest U.S. computer trade show.
The expansion drive, as well as issues of new shares to finance the buyouts, have worried some investors, who think the speed of growth too fast.
Softbank has forecast a parent current profit of 19 billion yen ($170 million) for the year to March 1997.
